column1: ap 02:43|Two-forty-three|"Jeeves—my man
column2: you know—is really a most extraordinary chap. So capable. Honestly
column3: I shouldn't know what to do without him. On broader lines he's like those chappies who sit peering sadly over the marble battlements at the Pennsylvania Station in the place marked “Inquiries.” You know the Johnnies I mean. You go up to them and say: “When's the next train for Melonsquashville
column8: change at San Francisco.” And they're right every time. Well
column9: Jeeves gives you just the same impression of omniscience."|"My Man Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: ap 10:00|"ten o'clock"|"“Pull yourself together
column2: Jeeves
column3: my man
column6: for I bar practical jokes before breakfast. “You know perfectly well there's no one waiting for me in the sitting-room. How could there be when it's barely ten o'clock yet?”"|"My Man Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: ap 08:00|eight|"This made the thing a bit more plausible. I remembered that when I had arrived in America about a year before
column2: the proceedings had begun at some ghastly hour like six
column3: and that I had been shot out on to a foreign shore considerably before eight."|"My Man Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: 12:00|midday|"“I am leaving New York by the midday train
column2: as I have to pay a visit to Sing-Sing prison. I am extremely interested in prison conditions in America. After that I work my way gradually across to the coast
column3: visiting the points of interest on the journey. You see
column5: I am in America principally on business. No doubt you read my book
column6: India and the Indians? My publishers are anxious for me to write a companion volume on the United States. I shall not be able to spend more than a month in the country
column7: as I have to get back for the season
column8: but a month should be ample. I was less than a month in India
column9: and my dear friend Sir Roger Cremorne wrote his America from Within after a stay of only two weeks. I should love to take dear Motty with me
column10: but the poor boy gets so sick when he travels by train. I shall have to pick him up on my return.”"|"My Man Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: ~ 12:00|"About midday"|"About midday Motty's luggage arrived
column2: and soon afterward a large parcel of what I took to be nice books. I brightened up a little when I saw it. It was one of those massive parcels and looked as if it had enough in it to keep the chappie busy for a year. I felt a trifle more cheerful
column3: and I got my Country Gentleman hat and stuck it on my head
column4: and gave the pink tie a twist
column5: and reeled out to take a bite of lunch with one or two of the lads at a neighbouring hostelry; and what with excellent browsing and sluicing and cheery conversation and what-not
column6: the afternoon passed quite happily. By dinner-time I had almost forgotten blighted Motty's existence."|"My Man Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: ~ 02:00|"about 2 a.m."|"It was shortly after this that young Motty got the idea of bringing pals back in the small hours to continue the gay revels in the home. This was where I began to crack under the strain. You see
column2: the part of town where I was living wasn't the right place for that sort of thing. I knew lots of chappies down Washington Square way who started the evening at about 2 a.m.—artists and writers and what-not
column3: who frolicked considerably till checked by the arrival of the morning milk. That was all right. They like that sort of thing down there. The neighbours can't get to sleep unless there's someone dancing Hawaiian dances over their heads. But on Fifty-seventh Street the atmosphere wasn't right
column4: and when Motty turned up at three in the morning with a collection of hearty lads
column5: who only stopped singing their college song when they started singing “The Old Oaken Bucket
column6: ” there was a marked peevishness among the old settlers in the flats. The management was extremely terse over the telephone at breakfast-time
column7: and took a lot of soothing."|"My Man Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: 03:00|"three in the morning"|"It was shortly after this that young Motty got the idea of bringing pals back in the small hours to continue the gay revels in the home. This was where I began to crack under the strain. You see
column2: the part of town where I was living wasn't the right place for that sort of thing. I knew lots of chappies down Washington Square way who started the evening at about 2 a.m.—artists and writers and what-not
column3: who frolicked considerably till checked by the arrival of the morning milk. That was all right. They like that sort of thing down there. The neighbours can't get to sleep unless there's someone dancing Hawaiian dances over their heads. But on Fifty-seventh Street the atmosphere wasn't right
column4: and when Motty turned up at three in the morning with a collection of hearty lads
column5: who only stopped singing their college song when they started singing “The Old Oaken Bucket
column6: ” there was a marked peevishness among the old settlers in the flats. The management was extremely terse over the telephone at breakfast-time
column7: and took a lot of soothing."|"My Man Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: ap 09:00|"nine o'clock"|"Do you know Marvis Bay? It's in Dorsetshire. It isn't what you'd call a fiercely exciting spot
column2: but it has its good points. You spend the day there bathing and sitting on the sands
column3: and in the evening you stroll out on the shore with the gnats. At nine o'clock you rub ointment on the wounds and go to bed."|"My Man Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: ap 08:00|"eight o'clock"|"Looking back at it
column2: I see that what saved me from Colney Hatch in that crisis was my bright idea of buying up most of the contents of the local sweet-shop. By serving out sweets to the kid practically incessantly we managed to get through the rest of that day pretty satisfactorily. At eight o'clock he fell asleep in a chair
column3: and
column4: having undressed him by unbuttoning every button in sight and
column7: we carried him up to bed."|"My Man Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: 07:00|"seven o'clock in the morning"|"Looking back
column2: I may say that
column3: so far as I was mixed up in it
column4: the thing began at seven o'clock in the morning
column5: when I was aroused from a dreamless sleep by the dickens of a scrap in progress outside my state-room door. The chief ingredients were a female voice that sobbed and said: “Oh
column6: Harold!” and a male voice “raised in anger
column9: I identified as Voules's. I hardly recognized it. In his official capacity Voules talks exactly like you'd expect a statue to talk
column12: he evidently relaxed to some extent
column13: and to have that sort of thing going on in my midst at that hour was too much for me."|"My Man Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: ap 06:00|"six o'clock"|"It was close on six o'clock when our third visitor of the day arrived. We were sitting on the afterdeck in the cool of the evening—old Marshall
column2: Denman Sturgis
column3: Mrs. Vanderley
column6: and I—when he came up. We had been talking of George
column7: and old Marshall was suggesting the advisability of sending out search-parties. He was worried. So was Stella Vanderley. So
column10: only not for the same reason."|"My Man Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: 01:00|"one o'clock in the morning"|"I don't know if you happen to be one of those Johnnies who are steeped in crime
column2: and so forth
column3: and think nothing of pinching diamond necklaces. If you're not
column4: you'll understand that I felt a lot less keen on the job I'd taken on when I sat in my room
column6: than I had done when I promised to tackle it in the dining-room. On paper it all seemed easy enough
column7: but I couldn't help feeling there was a catch somewhere
column8: and I've never known time pass slower. The kick-off was scheduled for one o'clock in the morning
column9: when the household might be expected to be pretty sound asleep
column10: but at a quarter to I couldn't stand it any longer. I lit the lantern I had taken from Bill's bicycle
column11: took a grip of my knife
column12: and slunk downstairs."|"My Man Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: ap 03:15|three-fifteen|"“Reggie
column2: ” said Bill
column3: “I happen to know there's a milk-train leaving Midford at three-fifteen. It isn't what you'd call a flier. It gets to London at about half-past nine. Well—er—in the circumstances
column4: how about it?”"|"My Man Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: ap ~ 09:30|"about half-past nine"|"“Reggie
column2: ” said Bill
column3: “I happen to know there's a milk-train leaving Midford at three-fifteen. It isn't what you'd call a flier. It gets to London at about half-past nine. Well—er—in the circumstances
column4: how about it?”"|"My Man Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: ap 00:00|twelve|"Rocky
column2: you see
column3: lived down on Long Island somewhere
column4: miles away from New York; and not only that
column5: but he had told me himself more than once that he never got up before twelve
column6: and seldom earlier than one. Constitutionally the laziest young devil in America
column7: he had hit on a walk in life which enabled him to go the limit in that direction. He was a poet. At least
column8: he wrote poems when he did anything; but most of his time
column9: as far as I could make out
column10: he spent in a sort of trance. He told me once that he could sit on a fence
column11: watching a worm and wondering what on earth it was up to
column12: for hours at a stretch."|"My Man Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: 16:00|"four in the afternoon"|"It was printed opposite the frontispiece of a magazine with a sort of scroll round it
column2: and a picture in the middle of a fairly-nude chappie
column3: with bulging muscles
column4: giving the rising sun the glad eye. Rocky said they gave him a hundred dollars for it
column5: and he stayed in bed till four in the afternoon for over a month."|"My Man Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: 17:00|"five in the afternoon"|"“I won't do it! I can't do it! I'll be hanged if I'll do it! How on earth can I dress up like that? Do you realize that most days I don't get out of my pyjamas till five in the afternoon
column2: and then I just put on an old sweater?”"|"My Man Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: 00:00|Midnight|"Jeeves was happy
column2: partly because he loves to exercise his giant brain
column3: and partly because he was having a corking time among the bright lights. I saw him one night at the Midnight Revels. He was sitting at a table on the edge of the dancing floor
column4: doing himself remarkably well with a fat cigar and a bottle of the best. I'd never imagined he could look so nearly human. His face wore an expression of austere benevolence
column5: and he was making notes in a small book."|"My Man Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: 00:00|Midnight|"“I was out with some of the crowd at the Midnight Revels the other
night. We took in a show first
column2: after a little dinner at a new

column1: place on Forty-third Street. We were quite a gay party. Georgie
Cohan looked in about midnight and got off a good one about Willie
Collier. Fred Stone could only stay a minute
column2: but Doug. Fairbanks

column1: did all sorts of stunts and made us roar. Diamond Jim Brady was
there
column2: as usual
column3: and Laurette Taylor showed up with a party. The

column1: show at the Revels is quite good. I am enclosing a programme."|"My Man Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

00:00|Midnight|"“The Midnight Revels. We've been here an hour
column2: and I think we're a fixture for the night. I've told Aunt Isabel I've gone out to call up a friend to join us. She's glued to a chair
column3: with this-is-the-life written all over her
column4: taking it in through the pores. She loves it
column5: and I'm nearly crazy.”"|"My Man Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: ap 07:30|"half-past seven"|"“I hope so
column2: ” said Rocky
column3: in the most unpleasant way. His troubles seemed to have had the worst effect on his character. “I should like to get back at them somehow; they've given me a bad enough time. They're about three sizes too small
column4: and something's apt to give at any moment. I wish to goodness it would
column5: and give me a chance to breathe. I haven't breathed since half-past seven. Thank Heaven
column6: Jeeves managed to get out and buy me a collar that fitted
column7: or I should be a strangled corpse by now! It was touch and go till the stud broke. Bertie
column8: this is pure Hades! Aunt Isabel keeps on urging me to dance. How on earth can I dance when I don't know a soul to dance with? And how the deuce could I
column9: even if I knew every girl in the place? It's taking big chances even to move in these trousers. I had to tell her I've hurt my ankle. She keeps asking me when Cohan and Stone are going to turn up; and it's simply a question of time before she discovers that Stone is sitting two tables away. Something's got to be done
column10: Bertie! You've got to think up some way of getting me out of this mess. It was you who got me into it.”"|"My Man Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"
